Article Title: Robots are scaring Chinese government, and the 'reason' is these 150-plus companies
Article Text:
Representative image

China vs US: Battle line drawn in robots race





Chinese government has a new 'scare' and it is the country's humanoid robotics industry. China’s burgeoning humanoid robotics sector, recently anointed a key economic catalyst by the Communist Party, is said to be attracting such an intense wave of investment that it is beginning to make Beijing uneasy. According to a report in Bloomberg, China’s powerful economic-planning agency has warned of the risks of a bubble forming in the country’s humanoid robotics industry, issuing a rare official expression of concern about a pivotal sphere of technology. The warning comes from China's National Development and Reform Commission, which sets economic strategy and shifts in policy. The agency has called attention to the proliferation of remarkably similar robots from more than 150 companies in the same field. Agency spokeswoman Li Chao told Bloomberg that it is important for the country to prevent this flood of humanoid robots from overwhelming the market and squeezing out real research and development initiatives. “Frontier industries have long grappled with the challenge of balancing the speed of growth against the risk of bubbles — an issue now confronting the humanoid robot sector as well,” Li added.The Chinese government's call for increased vigilance reflects growing anxiety over potential over-investment, an issue that has plagued past Chinese tech booms like bike-sharing and semiconductors, often resulting in market shakeups and consolidation.The development and funding frenzy has skyrocketed following Unitree Robotics' viral performance during the Spring Festival Gala earlier this year, where its dancing droids captivated a nationwide audience. This surge in interest aligns with the ruling Communist Party's new guidelines, which designated the humanoid robotics industry as one of six critical new economic growth drivers for China’s development plan through 2030.Investor enthusiasm is palpable. The Bloomberg report notes that the Solactive China Humanoid Robotics Index—which tracks the shares of robot-related companies—is up nearly 30% this year. Industry leader UBTech Robotics Corp., a potential beneficiary of any market consolidation, saw its shares gain more than 4% on Friday. Citigroup Inc. has projected the market could swell to $7 trillion by 2050, though widespread adoption of these robots in homes and factories is still considered years away. In 2023, China reportedly installed over 290,000 industrial robots, more than the rest of the world combined, with robot density reaching 470 robots per 10,000 workers, surpassing Japan and Germany for the first time.The sector's profile has been further elevated by key government endorsements. Unitree founder Wang Xingxing secured a front-row seat at a seminal meeting in February with President Xi Jinping and other prominent tech leaders, including Jack Ma. Since then, droids from fast-growing startups such as AgiBot and Galbot have become social media sensations, showcasing capabilities like running marathons, kickboxing, and making coffee.The government's plan, according to the official, is two-fold: accelerating research and development of core technologies while simultaneously supporting the construction of essential training and testing infrastructure. Furthermore, Beijing intends to "promote the consolidation and sharing of technology and industrial resources in the sector across the nation," in a bid to hasten the real-world application of humanoid robots.Chinese and American companies have begun a battle to build the world’s best robots. While it’s early days, experts say that China is leading in the quantity of robots delivered to consumers, while the US is ahead in the quality of robots demonstrated. China dominates in mass production and affordability; U.S. companies lead in technological sophistication and artificial intelligence capabilities, establishing a new tech rivalry. CEO Elon Musk danced with Tesla’s Optimus robots at his company’s shareholder meeting and outlined plans for a factory in Fremont that he said will someday have the capacity to build a million bots a year, which would sell for around $20,000 in today’s dollars.
Article Summary: China's economic-planning agency has warned of the risks of a bubble forming in the country's humanoid robotics industry. The warning comes from China's National Development and Reform Commission, which sets economic strategy and shifts in policy. The agency has called attention to the proliferation of remarkably similar robots from more than 150 companies in the same field.

Article Title: iPhone users finally learn why some callers are hidden and others are simply ‘unknown’
Article Text:
Apple Commnunity

Unknown Caller

No Caller ID

The Slimmest iPhone Yet: What we think

When you see “No Caller ID”

doesn’t want their identity displayed.

When you see “Unknown Caller”

No Caller ID means the caller refused to show the number.

Unknown Caller means the number itself got lost en route.

The way we respond to each

No Caller ID

Unknown Caller





On the surface, both labels feel identical: a call appears, you don’t recognise it, and your instinct is to reject and sigh. But these two phrases don’t mean the same thing, and once you understand the difference, the mystery of these silent numbers suddenly makes more sense.Let’s start with the human reaction. Most of us will simply let these calls ring out. There’s the gut-level suspicion: if someone really had something to say, they’d text, leave a voicemail, or call from a visible number. And people on Reddit Apple Community forums and countless user discussions echo the same sentiment, confusion, curiosity and a small underlying paranoia. One Apple Community user even described being “spooked” when their phone displayed, insisting they knew the same person had called earlier asand couldn’t figure out why the wording changed.That’s where the difference lies.This happens when the caller actively chooses to hide their number. The caller either changes their device settings to block their ID, or manually prefixes the call (such as dialling 141 in the UK or *67 in the US) to conceal it. In other words, the phone knows exactly who’s calling, it just isn’t allowed to show you.This can be used by scam callers, yes, but it also appears when medical professionals, journalists, government departments or private investigators make outbound calls and don’t want a return call coming back through the same number. There is intent behind the concealment, someoneThis tells a very different story. Here, the network isn’t hiding the number, it simply never successfully received it. On “Unknown Caller,” the caller isn’t necessarily trying to hide anything. The system attempted to provide caller ID, but somewhere between sending and receiving, the data fell apart. That can happen with international routing, inter-carrier incompatibilities or telecom glitches that interrupt identification.Think of it this way:This is why you might see an unknown call from your own bank, your mum’s old mobile, or a landline, even though none of them were deliberately masking anything. The uncertainty isn’t intentional; it’s technical.There’s a psychological split too, and you see it in real user behaviour. People treatas something to distrust, almost adversarially. Meanwhile,is unsettling in a different way, it feels like a blank space, a glitch. There’s room for it to be innocent, and room for it to be fraudulent.So the next time your screen lights up with one of those anonymous labels, you’re not staring at two versions of the same thing. You’re looking at two different mechanisms of anonymity, one chosen by the caller, the other imposed by the network.
Article Summary: Unknown Caller means the number itself got lost en route. No Caller ID means the caller actively chooses to hide their number. This happens when the caller either changes their device settings to block their ID, or manually prefixes the call (such as dialling 141 in the UK or *67 in the US)

Article Title: Government tells WhatsApp, Telegram and others to link services to SIM cards: What it means for users
Article Text:
What it means for multi-device users and travellers







The Union government has issued new directives requiring messaging apps to enforce SIM card verification and automatically log out web-based sessions every six hours. This means that users will be barred from accessing their services if they do not have a physical SIM card originally used to register for the app present in their device. The directive by the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) will affect major platforms including WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Arattai, Snapchat, Sharechat and others, and are aimed at combating cyber fraud.According to the notice, these communication apps must ensure within 90 days that their services remain “continuously” linked to the SIM card used during registration. They must block access if the SIM is not present in the device – a technical requirement known as SIM binding. Additionally, web-based versions of these apps, such as WhatsApp Web, must log out users periodically, with sessions not exceeding six hours.“It has come to the notice of Central Government that some of the app based communication services that are utilizing mobile number for identification of its customers... allow users to consume their services without availability of the underlying SIM within the device...posing challenge to telecom cyber security as it is being misused from outside the country to commit cyber-frauds,” DoT stated in its notice.The government is invoking powers from the Telecommunication Cybersecurity Amendment Rules, 2025, notified in October, which introduced the concept of Telecommunication Identifier User Entity (TIUE) under telecom regulations.WhatsApp has more than 500 million users in India, and the new regulations may hinder daily use. For example, some people use multiple devices, like phone and tablets, or two phones but link them to use one account on both the devices. They may experience disruptions due to the mandate of SIM binding.Further, people who use WhatsApp on their PCs to lessen their screen time on phone and restrict themselves to communication on messaging apps are likely to face disruption during work hours.“Presently, the binding process between a subscriber's app-based communication services and their mobile SIM card occurs only once during the initial installation and verification phase, after which the application continues to function independently on the device even if the SIM card is later removed, replaced or deactivated,” COAI previously stated.
Article Summary: New regulations require messaging apps to enforce SIM card verification. WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Arattai, Snapchat, Sharechat and others will have to comply. They must block access if the SIM is not present in the device – a technical requirement known as SIM binding.

ChatGPT-maker OpenAI is partnering with Taiwan's Foxconn to design and build artificial intelligence (AI) data centre components within the US. This partnership is the AI startup's newest step in its extensive infrastructure development plans. The companies stated the goal is to accelerate infrastructure deployment and secure long-term US capacity for essential AI components. While financial terms were not disclosed, OpenAI confirmed it will have early access to evaluate the systems produced by the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer and Apple ’s largest supplier, along with the option to purchase them.In a statement to CNBC, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman commented on the partnership, saying:adding that AI infrastructure presents aUnder the agreement, OpenAI and Foxconn will co-develop multiple generations of AI servers and manufacture core components, which include power, networking, and cooling systems, at Foxconn’s US facilities, which are located in Wisconsin, Ohio, Texas, Virginia and Indiana.Foxconn adds another manufacturing layer to OpenAI’s supply chain, which could help make production for the AI startup more local and speed up deployment.The company is widely known for assembling Apple’s iPhones, but it has also expanded into AI and automotive manufacturing. It builds server racks designed for AI workloads and is an important global supplier to Nvidia, a major producer of high-end AI chips.Chairman Young Liu said to CNBC.However, the company has had mixed results in the US. In 2018, Foxconn began construction of a large factory in Wisconsin intended to make flat-panel displays. The project did not succeed, and the site is now being used for an AI data centre under construction by Microsoft.OpenAI has recently made several major agreements with some of the world’s biggest technology companies, announcing spending plans of about $1.4 trillion.These commitments have raised questions about whether the company will eventually generate enough profit to support that level of investment.Earlier this month, Altman said the company expects to reach $20 billion in annualised revenue by the end of the year and aims to reach hundreds of billions by 2030.Previous deals include a $100 billion agreement (yet to be finalised) with Nvidia, under which the chipmaker would invest in OpenAI in phases as the company expands its infrastructure.OpenAI also has cloud partnerships with Microsoft, Google, and Amazon, as well as significant compute buildout commitments with Oracle.

Article Title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang to employees at town hall: Market not happy with our results, did you check memes on the internet

Nvidia’s quarterly results







Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang recently struck a humorous and candid tone in the company’s recent Townhall with the employees. You should’ve seen some of the memes on the internet. We’re basically holding the planet together — and it’s not untrue.”Nvidia reported a record quarter with $57 billion revenue which is up by 62% year-over-year, and forecasted $65 billion for the fourth quarter. If we delivered a great quarter, we are fueling the AI bubble,” Huang told employees, according to a Business Insider report.Along with this, Huang also said that he was ‘delighted’ with the company’s results and proud of employees. He further added that Nvidia’s massive influence has made expectations harder to meet a reality reflected in its volatile market value.Huang lightheartedly recalled the “good old days” when Nvidia’s market cap stood at $5 trillion, joking about the company’s recent valuation swings, “Nobody in history has ever lost $500 billion in a few weeks. Article Title: ‘Rough news but…’: Netflix shuts down studio behind game that hit number 1 in 26 countries

Netflix shift in gaming strategy







Netflix has shut down the game studio Boss Fight Entertainment, the developer behind the hit mobile game Squid Game: Unleashed. The closure comes as the streaming giant pivots its strategy within its expanding video gaming unit, a report has said.The studio’s co-founder and former CEO, David Rippy, confirmed the closure in a LinkedIn post this week. He said that the studio is “very grateful for the time” it had at Netflix. Read Rippy’s full post on LinkedIn.Hi everyone – well, word has gotten around quickly about Boss Fight’s closure. Thanks, everyone who reached out today. Rough news, for sure, but I’m very grateful for the time we had at Netflix. We worked with some awesome people and made many games that I’m very proud of, including Squid Game Unleased which hit #1 in 26 countries. You’ll see lots of Boss Fighters with similar posts. As for Bill, Scott and me – we’re going to take a little breather before tackling whatever is next. Love to hear from you if there’s anything interesting going on, workwise or otherwise.Another employee, David Luehmann, a director of game development at the studio, also posted on LinkedIn, saying, "After 10+ great years working at Boss Fight, the last few as part of Netflix, the time has come for the studio to close down."“I am very proud of all the people, work, and games we've released. Article Title: South Korea’s biggest online retailer Coupang 'hacked': Name, email, phone number and other personal data of 33.7 million customers leaked
Article Text:

Coupang, South Korea's largest e-commerce platform often dubbed the “Amazon.com of South Korea,” has said that its systems were illegally accessed causing a massive data breach and affecting the personal information of 33.7 million customer accounts. The breach was first detected by the company on November 18 but it believes the unauthorised access to customer accounts began on June 24 and was executed through overseas servers.Coupang says that the compromised information is limited to basic personal data and the highly sensitive financial details remain secure. The exposed data includes name, email address, phone number, shipping address, and certain order histories. The company, however, said that payment information, credit card numbers and login credentials were not accessed by hackers, according to The Korea Herald.“Unauthorized access to delivery-related personal information for the affected accounts appears to have been made through overseas servers since June 24. The access route has been blocked and internal monitoring strengthened,” Coupang said.The data breach has affected nearly all of the company’s extensive customer base.Coupang is known for its “Rocket" fast deliveries.Coupang has also apologised for the data leak and urged customers to be wary of phone calls, text messages or other communications impersonating the company. The company also said that it has launched an investigation with security experts into the incident and is working with law enforcement as well as regulatory authorities.Notably, on November 20, Coupang reported a data leak involving about 4,500 customers. At that time, the company said that it had found no evidence of unauthorised access to payment information or into its systems.The latest incident surpasses SK Telecom's data leak in April. It affected 23.2 million users, resulting in a record fine of 134.8 billion won.
Article Summary: Coupang, South Korea's largest e-commerce platform, has said that its systems were illegally accessed causing a massive data breach. The compromised information is limited to basic personal data and the highly sensitive financial details remain secure.

Article Title: When Bill Gates told Halo game maker, 'Steve Jobs can't have that, we are...'
Article Text:
Microsoft's 2000 acquisition of Bungie Studios, spurred by a 1999 Macworld demo of Halo with Steve Jobs, secured a flagship franchise for the then-upcoming Xbox. Initially a Mac-exclusive concept, Microsoft's timely offer rescued a struggling Bungie and transformed Halo into a system-defining, billion-dollar success that reshaped console gaming.

Bill Gates No Longer among Top 10 Billionaires: The Real Reason

From Apple's stage to Xbox's cornerstone

How a struggling studio became Xbox's billion-dollar franchise





Microsoft's acquisition of Bungie Studios in 2000 came after the gaming company showcased Halo on stage with Apple's Steve Jobs at Macworld 1999, according to Halo co-creator Marcus Lehto. The move transformed what would have been a Mac-exclusive title into Xbox's flagship franchise.Lehto revealed that Microsoft executives reached out shortly after the Macworld presentation, where Bungie demonstrated an early version of Halo as a third-person shooter for Macintosh computers. The tech giant saw an opportunity to secure a killer app for its upcoming Xbox console launch."We got up on stage with Steve Jobs at Macworld and we talked about it there," Lehto recalled in an interview with Kent State Magazine. "And then Microsoft said, 'Steve Jobs can't have that. We're going to buy you and move you all to the Pacific Northwest, and then we're going to have you build this game for the Xbox.'"The acquisition proved strategically brilliant. Halo: Combat Evolved launched alongside the original Xbox in 2001, becoming the system-defining title that helped establish Microsoft's gaming division. The franchise has since generated billions in revenue and spawned numerous sequels, spin-offs, and adaptations.At the time of Microsoft's approach, Bungie was facing financial difficulties, making the buyout offer particularly timely. Lehto, who served as art director and designed the iconic Master Chief character through nine iterations, said the partnership represented perfect timing for both companies.The game that Jobs introduced to the world looked dramatically different from the final product. The Macworld demo featured aliens and an epic soundtrack but was otherwise unrecognizable compared to the first-person shooter that revolutionized console gaming.Today, Halo remains synonymous with Xbox, proving Microsoft's aggressive acquisition strategy paid off in ways that reshaped the gaming industry's competitive landscape for decades to come.
Article Summary: Microsoft's acquisition of Bungie Studios in 2000 came after the gaming company showcased Halo on stage with Apple's Steve Jobs. The move transformed what would have been a Mac-exclusive title into Xbox's flagship franchise. Halo: Combat Evolved launched alongside the original Xbox in 2001, becoming the system- defining title that helped establish Microsoft's gaming division.

Article Title: French President Emmanuel Macron: Don't Blame Russia for inaction on Microsoft, Apple, Facebook; because there’s an American...
Article Text:
France's President Macron criticizes Brussels for slow enforcement of EU digital laws, blaming US pressure, not Russian interference. He highlighted stalled investigations under the Digital Services Act, citing fear among officials of an "American offensive." This comes as the US reportedly uses trade tariffs as leverage to influence the EU's tech regulations, prompting accusations of "blackmail" from EU officials.

US trade pressure mounts on EU tech rulebook

Commission defends enforcement amid political pressure





French President Emmanuel Macron has accused Brussels of moving too slowly on investigations into American tech giants, claiming that US pressure—not Russian interference—is stalling the European Union's enforcement of its digital regulations.Speaking at a town hall event in the Vosges region of northeastern France, Macron singled out cases that have languished before the European Commission for two years under the Digital Services Act (DSA), calling the pace "much too slow." According to Politico, the French leader warned that many officials at both the Commission and member state level "are afraid to pursue it because there's an American offensive against the application of directives on digital services and markets. "Macron's remarks followed a contentious week in Brussels, where US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick pressed EU ministers to "reconsider" the bloc's tech regulations in exchange for reduced steel and aluminum tariffs. The move represents Washington's strategy of treating European digital rules as bargaining chips in transatlantic trade negotiations, Politico reported.The EU's DSA and Digital Markets Act have become flashpoints since President Donald Trump returned to office, with both U.S.officials and tech executives lobbying against the regulations. Lutnick suggested the EU could attract $1 trillion in US investment—primarily through AI-powered data centers—if it adopted a "balanced approach" to digital rules.European Commission spokesperson Thomas Regnier defended the institution's commitment to its digital legislation, stating officials are "building solid cases, because we have to win them in court." He noted that DSA investigations are comprehensive and some naturally take longer than others.The Commission currently has open investigations into X, Meta, AliExpress, Temu, and TikTok under the DSA. These probes could result in fines up to 6 percent of a company's annual global revenue, though none have been levied yet.EU tech chief Henna Virkkunen and competition commissioner Teresa Ribera both pushed back against US pressure this week, with Ribera accusing Washington of "blackmail." Meanwhile, the European Parliament's Socialists and Democrats group is moving to establish an inquiry committee to investigate the EU's enforcement of digital rules.
Article Summary: French President Emmanuel Macron criticizes Brussels for slow enforcement of EU digital laws, blaming US pressure. Article Text:
Talent shortage poses challenge for Tata Electronics







Tata Electronics is reportedly preparing to expand its workforce at its Tamil Nadu facility. According top a report, the company’s hiring push will bring total headcount at the Hosur plant to 75,000 from the current 60,000 – essentially adding 15,000 employees over the next six months as it races to keep pace with surging demand from Apple . Article Title: Explained: What is the Airbus A320 software issue and why are 6,000 planes grounded
Article Text:
Airbus has grounded 6,000 A320 aircraft—half its global fleet—for emergency software fixes after discovering intense solar radiation can corrupt critical flight control systems. The unprecedented recall follows an October incident when a JetBlue flight suddenly nosedived without pilot input, forcing an emergency landing. Airlines worldwide face massive disruptions during peak travel season, with repairs taking hours for most planes but weeks for 1,000 older jets requiring hardware replacements. The incident is being hailed as the largest aircraft recall in history.

IndiGo And Air India Warn Of Delays As Airbus Solar Radiation Snag Hits 350 A320 Jets In India

Airlines scramble as thousands of aircrafts grounded worldwide

Software fixes vary by aircraft age and configuration: Two-thirds jets get quick fix, but 1,000 older jets face extended downtime

How solar storms threaten modern aviation electronics

Largest recall in Airbus's 55-year history





Airbus has ordered software updates for approximately 6,000 A320 family aircrafts—more than half its global fleet—after discovering that intense solar radiation can corrupt critical flight control systems, triggering one of the largest aircraft recalls in aviation history. The emergency directive, issued November 29, has caused widespread flight cancellations and delays worldwide, affecting millions of passengers during the peak US Thanksgiving travel weekend.The action follows an October 30 incident when a JetBlue flight from Cancun to Newark suddenly nosedived without pilot input, injuring several passengers and forcing an emergency landing in Tampa, Florida. Investigators traced the malfunction to the aircraft's ELAC 2 computer—which controls elevator and aileron surfaces—after intense solar radiation corrupted data essential to maintaining stable flight."Intense solar radiation may corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls," Airbus stated, acknowledging the fixes would create "operational disruptions to passengers and customers." The European Union Aviation Safety Agency immediately issued an emergency airworthiness directive prohibiting affected aircraft from flying until repairs are completed.The recall's timing couldn't be worse. Over seven million Americans were expected to fly during Thanksgiving weekend, and four of the world's ten largest A320 operators—American Airlines, Delta, JetBlue, and United—are US carriers facing immediate pressure to restore service.American Airlines initially reported 340 affected aircraft before revising the count to 209, stating most repairs would be completed within 48 hours at approximately two hours per plane. Delta expected limited operational impact with updates finished by Saturday morning. However, Colombian carrier Avianca closed ticket sales through December 8 after determining 70 percent of its fleet required fixes.The disruption rippled globally. Air France cancelled 35 flights Friday. Japan's ANA Holdings grounded dozens of aircraft, cancelling 65 Saturday flights. Indian carriers IndiGo and Air India warned passengers of delays and possible cancellations. Airlines from Germany's Lufthansa to UK-based EasyJet and Air New Zealand all reported varying degrees of service interruption.For roughly 4,000 aircraft, the solution involves reverting to earlier software versions—a relatively simple procedure taking a few hours. But approximately 1,000 older jets require complete hardware replacements, threatening groundings lasting weeks depending on parts availability and maintenance capacity.The disruption compounds existing aviation industry challenges. Airlines already face maintenance shop shortages and hundreds of grounded Airbus jets awaiting engine repairs. The sudden recall further strains limited resources during a critical revenue period.UK Transport Secretary Heidi Alexander offered reassurance that British impact appeared limited, with only small numbers requiring complex fixes. EasyJet reported completing updates proactively and planned normal Saturday operations. Air Canada stated few aircraft used the problematic software version and expected no operational impact.The A320 family revolutionised commercial aviation when launched in 1984 as the first mainstream aircraft using fly-by-wire technology—replacing mechanical controls with electronic systems. While this innovation improved efficiency and safety, it created new vulnerabilities to electromagnetic interference.The coronal mass ejections from the sun release heavily charged particles into Earth's atmosphere. At altitudes above 28,000 feet, these particles generate additional atmospheric radiation capable of corrupting aircraft electronics.The ELAC system translates pilot commands from cockpit side-sticks into electronic signals that control wing ailerons and tail elevators—the surfaces managing aircraft pitch and roll. When solar radiation corrupts ELAC data, the aircraft can execute uncommanded maneuvers, as passengers on the JetBlue flight discovered when their plane suddenly dropped altitude without warning.France's Thales, which manufactures the ELAC hardware, stated its computers comply fully with Airbus specifications and regulatory certifications, noting the vulnerable functionality involves software outside Thales's responsibility.The recall represents extraordinary scope for the aerospace giant. With approximately 11,300 A320-family aircraft operating worldwide, the affected 6,000 jets serve airlines across six continents. The A320 competes directly with Boeing's 737 as workhorses of global aviation, providing crucial connections that represent significant economic infrastructure.The setback arrives just weeks after the A320 surpassed the 737 as the most-delivered aircraft model in history—a milestone now overshadowed by safety concerns and operational chaos. Aviation analysts noted such widespread mandatory groundings remain exceptionally rare, though the industry's rapid response demonstrates robust safety protocols.Airbus emphasized it worked proactively with authorities to ensure fleet safety, apologizing for inconvenience while maintaining safety as its "number one and overriding priority."
Article Summary: Airbus has ordered software updates for approximately 6,000 A320 family aircrafts. Intense solar radiation can corrupt critical flight control systems, triggering one of the largest aircraft recalls in aviation history. The action follows an October 30 incident when a JetBlue flight suddenly nosedived without pilot input, forcing an emergency landing.

Article Title: Two reasons Apple is likely going back to Intel, five years after break-up

Article Title: Not convincing: France on dismissing local browser's antitrust case against Microsoft
Article Text:
What Microsoft said about French regulator’s decision

“We agree with the decision and remain committed to providing high-quality search services and fostering innovation for consumers and partners in France and across Europe.”

What French browser company Qwant alleged against Microsoft





France’s competition watchdog, the Autorité de la Concurrence, has rejected a complaint filed by the local search engine company Qwant against Microsoft. According to a report by the news agency Reuters, Qwant had accused the software giant of unfairly leveraging its market power. The French regulator said that Qwant did not provide enough convincing evidence to support these serious claims. As a result, the case was dismissed, and the regulator also refused to impose any temporary penalties on Microsoft that Qwant had requested.Microsoft welcomed the French regulators' ruling. In a statement ot Reuters, a Microsoft spokesperson said:Qwant accused Microsoft of placing limits on how Qwant could appear in search results and search advertising, making it harder for the French company to build its own search engine and develop its own artificial intelligence (AI) tools. Qwant also claimed that Microsoft received better treatment when allocating search ads.The company has long relied on Microsoft’s Bing to provide search and news results.Last month, Qwant said it expected its complaint to be dismissed and planned to challenge the decision in court or take it to other authorities.Microsoft remains a major provider of search results to smaller European search engines, including Ecosia, DuckDuckGo, Lilo and Qwant.In September, Microsoft avoided a major European Union fine by agreeing to separate its Teams app from its Office software and offer lower-priced options. The European Commission accepted these commitments, bringing an end to a long antitrust investigation that began after complaints from rival companies.The case started with a 2020 complaint from Slack, which Salesforce owns. Slack said Microsoft unfairly bundled Teams with Office 365 and Microsoft 365 to gain an unfair market advantage. Another complaint was filed in 2023 by the German company Alfaview, which increased pressure on regulators.Under the agreement, Microsoft offered versions of Office 365 and Microsoft 365 without Teams at prices 1 to 8 euros lower. The company also agreed to increase the price difference between bundled and unbundled versions by 50% for some business plans.Beyond pricing, Microsoft agreed to improve interoperability between Teams competitors and its own products. It also allowed users to export Teams chats to rival services and gave long-term Office customers the option to move to unbundled versions. Most of these commitments were set to last 7 years, while data portability and interoperability commitments would remain in place for 10 years. These changes were applied globally, not only in Europe.EU executive VPTeresa Ribera said the decision opened up more competition and helped businesses choose the tools they preferred. The agreement marked a more cooperative stance from Microsoft, which had previously faced 2.2 billion euros in EU fines for similar issues. By settling, Microsoft avoided penalties that could have reached up to 10% of its global annual revenue.
Article Summary: Qwant accused Microsoft of placing limits on how Qwant could appear in search results and search advertising. The French regulator said that Qwant did not provide enough convincing evidence to support these serious claims. In September, Microsoft avoided a major European Union fine by agreeing to separate its Teams app from its Office software.

Article Title: When two 22-year-old Chinese students said 'No' to Elon Musk's million-dollar job offer
Article Text:
Representative Image

What ‘breakthrough’ caught Musk’s attention







At a time when tech giants like Google , Facebook-parent Meta and ChatGPT-maker OpenAI are offering massive salaries to secure top AI talent, two 22-year-old Chinese students have revealed they turned down a multi-million dollar offer from Elon Musk ’s xAI. The friends, William Chen and Guan Wang, have claimed that they rejected the highly lucrative pay package to pursue a greater, high-stakes gamble: building a “brain-inspired” reasoning system that they believe will be the first to achieve Artificial General Intelligence (AGI).According to a report by Fortune, Chen and Wang said that they received an offer from Musk two years ago, following the viral success of the small large-language model (LLM) the students had developed, called OpenChat. Instead of training their model on massive internet data dumps, Chen and Wang used a small, carefully chosen set of high-quality conversations. In the process, they also pioneered the use of Reinforcement Learning (RL) to teach the model to refine its behaviour through feedback and rewards.They said that OpenChat quickly became famous in academic circles, cited by researchers at Berkeley and Stanford as a prime example of how a small model trained on good data could outperform systems based on sheer volume of data.The attention OpenChat received quickly landed in Elon Musk’s inbox, resulting in the multi-million dollar recruitment offer from his new company, xAI. However, Chen and Wang chose to reject the deal, by saying that current large-scale machine learning architecture was fundamentally limited.“We decided that large-language models have their limitations. We want a new architecture that will overcome the structural limitation of [large-scale machine learning],” Chen was quoted as saying.The pair dedicated two years to launch their new company, Sapient Intelligence whose model reportedly shows promise, outperforming some of the world’s biggest existing AI systems on tests of abstract reasoning.
Article Summary: Two 22-year-old Chinese students have revealed they turned down a multi-million dollar offer from Elon Musk ’s xAI. The friends, William Chen and Guan Wang, have claimed that they rejected the highly lucrative pay package to pursue a greater, high-stakes gamble: building a ‘brain-inspired’ reasoning system.
